sub_title: research physicist at Academisch Medisch Centrum
summary:
The subject of my research activities is hyperthermia, a cancer therapy involving raising the tumour temperature to 41-43C. Hyperthermia enhances the radiosensitivity and chemosensitivity of tumours and leads to significant improvement in tumour control and survival.
Emphasis in my research acitivities is to develop clinical hyperthermia equipment, with emphasis on system design and treatment planning. My position as principal investigator for hyperthermia includes responsability for clinical and preclinical hyperthermia research at the department.

projects.title: Improving therapeutic effectiveness and reducing toxicity of HIPEC for colorectal peritoneal metastases (PMCRC) by applying “step-up” heating (KWF UVA 2021-13420)
projects.description: KWF project with project leader J. Crezee, and PI's A.L. Oei, HP Kok, J Tuynman funded by Dutch Cancer Society KWF project UVA 2021-13420:  €606,530.50. Purpose is to devise, evaluate and optimize effectiveness established by cytotoxicity and penetration depth of HIPEC with oxaliplatin-based and MMC-based  regimes for PMCRC, by utilizing novel dynamic HIPEC protocols with sequential variation in dose, temperature level and duration of exposure to chemotherapy in in vitro, organoid, in vivo tumor models. Goal is to establish HIPEC strategies  resulting in effective tumor eradication without unacceptable local and systemic side effects.

contributors.headline: research physicist at Academisch Medisch Centrum

projects.title: Optimization of pancreatic cancer treatment using chemotherapy and hyperthermia
projects.description: Dutch Cancer Society project UVA 2020-12985 ‘Optimization of pancreatic cancer treatment using chemotherapy and hyperthermia’, project leader Petra Kok, co-PI’s Hans Crezee en Maarten Bijlsma. Total grant sum € 622.711,75. Aim of the study is to determine the optimal temperature within the 39-43°C range for chemosensitization in pancreatic cancer in a KPC mouse model of PDAC, using a recently developed dedicated hyperthermia device for pre-clinical research. This unique device consists of a phased array of miniature antennas positioned around a mouse, which permits well-controlled tumor heating, similar as in humans.

projects.title: HYPERBOOST: Hyperthermia boosting the effect of Radiotherapy
projects.description:
Coordinator: J Crezee
AMC EU office coordination: E Quartier, L Jongejan
WP leaders: J Crezee, BJ Slotman, MR Horsman, R Fietkau, GC van Rhoon
PI's: PM Krawczyk, MR Horsman, U Gaipl, S Scheidegger, HP Kok, GC van Rhoon, H Dobsicek Trefna, T Niendorf, O Ott/B Frey, P Wust, O Riesterer
co-PIs/mentors: S Bodis, P Ghadjar, RM Füchslin, G Sennewald, M Wadepohl, J Overgaard, R Fietkau, M Franckena, S Ciampa, M Persson, M Paulides, P Pavoni, LJA Stalpers, NAP Franken, AL Oei, A Bel, P Byrialsen Elming, D Marder, E Pagliaroli

The European Training Network “HYPERBOOST: Hyperthermia boosting the effect of Radiotherapy” (H2020-MSCA-ITN-2020-955625, project coordinator J. Crezee, total grant sum € 3,761,881.56) aims at training a new generation of creative and entrepreneurial professionals with the skills and expertise to coordinate, develop, apply and optimise advanced multi-modality cancer treatments. HYPERBOOST will also develop an advanced personalised treatment planning platform for hyperthermia based on extensive (pre)clinical data. To this end HYPERBOOST amalgamates an exceptional faculty, constitutes a role model for diversity, and represents a unique blend of international leaders in their fields, as well as excellent investigators at various career stages.

Eleven beneficiaries: Academic Medical Center Amsterdam, Aarhus University, Universität Zürich, Universitäts-klinikum Erlangen, Zurich University of Applied Sciences, Dr. Sennewald Medizintechnik GmbH Munich, Medlogix Rome, Charité – Universitäts-medizin Berlin, Chalmers University of technology Göteborg, Erasmus Medical Center Rotterdam, Max-Delbrück Center for Molecular Medicine in the Helmholtz Association, Berlin

Six partner organisations:PO1 Duke University Medical Center, European Society for Radiotherapy & Oncology (ESTRO), European Society for Hyperthermic Oncology (ESHO), RaySearch Laboratories AB Stockholm, University of Amsterdam, MRI.Tools GmbH Berlin

contributors.headline: research physicist at Academisch Medisch Centrum

projects.title: Clinical evaluation of the benefit of planning based steering to improve effectiveness of hyperthermia in cervical cancer patients  (KWF UVA 2017-10873)
projects.description:
Project leaders: HP Kok, J Crezee, LJA Stalpers.
Hyperthermia, i.e. heating of tumor tissue to 40-43°C, is applied combined with radiotherapy or chemotherapy and triggers multiple mechanisms (e.g. inhibition of DNA damage repair) that sensitize tumor cells to radiotherapy and chemotherapy. 
Hyperthermia is usually applied with locoregional systems consisting of multiple radiofrequency antennas around the patient. The resulting power and temperature distribution is controlled by the individual antenna settings (i.e. phases and amplitudes). These settings are adapted during treatment based on continuous temperature measurements in the tumor and the patient’s feedback when normal tissue temperatures get too high (i.e. treatment limiting hot spots). The large number of degrees of freedom in power steering makes establishing optimal settings very difficult; tumor temperatures thus often remain suboptimal. 

Solution: We have developed a treatment planning(TP) module for on-line adaptive hyperthermia treatment planning, which is used during treatment to visualize results of adapting antenna settings and support more effective power steering. We demonstrated its effectiveness in suppressing hot spots. 

Aim: To determine whether treatment planning-based power steering is more effective than experience-based power steering. This will be done by double blind randomization between experience-based and planning-based interventions in patients.

Plan of investigation: HT is usually applied in 5 weekly sessions combined with RT or CH. During each 60min session, hot spots occur that require intervention to adapt power steering. We randomize during each session between experience-based and planning-based interventions for each hot spot complaint. The first 1.5 years is dedicated to development of a graphical user interface(GUI) to perform the clinical evaluation. The actual study and analysis are performed in the last 2.5 years.

projects.title: A dedicated high resolution small animal hyperthermia device to support translation of novel cancer therapies from lab to bedside
projects.description: Investment grant NWO medium, principal applicant J. Crezee, co-applicant N.A.P. Franken. Goal is development and construction of a small animal hyperthermia device for cancer research. The new hyperthermia device will be used in research projects investigating various aspects of multimodality treatment of cancer. A range of important topics is covered including the optimal schedule of combining hyperthermia and radiotherapy and other cancer treatments, the effect of hyperthermia on tumor hypoxia, the use of hyperthermia to focus chemotherapy delivery to the tumor, to improve the effect of chemotherapy in brain tumors and to target the treatment–resistant cancer stem cells. Participating researchers are leaders in their field from four academic medical centers: AMC-University of Amsterdam, VUmc-Free University Amsterdam, Maastro – University of Maastricht and ErasmusMC, Rotterdam, and the TU Delft

projects.title: Optimization of loco-regional bladder hyperthermia treatment by using improved thermometry and 3D hyperthermia treatment planning KWF (UVA 2012-5539)
projects.description:
Major challenges in the treatment of intermediate/high risk non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) are the 30-40% recurrence rate and risk of progression, despite treatment with immunotherapy and/or chemotherapy. Recently, promising results were obtained by combining MMC with intracavitary hyperthermia (HT). However, intracavitary HT techniques are associated with large temperature differences, locoregional HT is expected to yield a more uniform tumor temperature. A pilot study at AMC showed locoregional HT and MMC for intermediate/high risk NMIBC is feasible with excellent bladder temperatures of 42°C and minimal toxicity. Thermometry during bladder HT was limited to intraluminal measurements along the central axis of the bladder and absent at the bladder wall. The latter is more representative for residual tumor sites.
  
4 Purpose
The purpose is to optimize the temperature distribution during locoregional bladder HT treatment by using three dimensional (3D) steering of the temperature rise, guided by high resolution Hyperthermia Treatment Planning (HTP) and guided by improved 3D temperature data, obtained by developing a new probe to monitor the bladder wall temperature distribution.

projects.title: ONLINE HOT SPOT SUPPRESSION TO IMPROVE LOCOREGIONAL HYPERTHERMIA TREATMENTS KWF (UVA 2012-5393)
projects.description:
Hyperthermia (HT), the application of elevated temperatures (41-45°C) to tumor tissue, is a powerful radio and chemo sensitizer. Randomised trials have demonstrated a significant improvement in tumor control and patient survival for cervical and other cancer sites by combining radiotherapy and HT. The results of clinical trials were positive in spite of the fact that goal temperatures rarely achieved in the tumor due to the incidence of unwanted hot spots in normal tissue. Clinical results can improve further when these treatment limiting hot spots could be suppressed. The 3-D power control of the latest generation phased array antenna systems for locoregional HT is capable of preventing hot spots. However, manual optimization of system settings is very difficult due to the large number of degrees of freedom of these systems, and pre treatment planning is presently not yet sufficiently reliable due to uncertainty in input data. 
To develop treatment planning guided active hot spot suppression to improve tumor temperatures. The method should be applicable for all locoregional HT patients.
Development and implementation of active hot spot suppression involves three steps: 
i.	Development of algorithms capable of adapting phase and amplitude settings to suppress hot spots occurring at any possible location.
ii.	Pre-clinical tests: Computer simulations will be used to predict the performance of the developed algorithms under realistic clinical conditions, with emphasis on performance with limited temperature and E-field data, and uncertainty in tissue properties.
iii.	Clinical validation: The performance of the algorithm will be validated in 20 cervical cancer patients treated with hyperthermia using the 70 MHz AMC-8 regional HT system. Each patient will receive five HT sessions, and each HT session will start with standard experience based phase and amplitude settings.

projects.title: Active hot spot suppression to improve thermal dose and clinical outcome of locoregional hyperthermia treatments
projects.description: Research project granted by the Dutch Cancer Society Koningin Wilhelmina Fonds (KWF UVA 2012 5393) aiming at using fast adaptive hyperthermia treatment planning to respond to patient complaints during hyperthermia treatment by computing new system settings to suppress hot spots leading to complaints, ultimately resulting in higher tumor temperatures. projects.title: Improved regional hyperthermia delivery by using MRI data for treatment planning KWF (UVA 2010-4660)
projects.description:
Hyperthermia (HT) is a powerful, clinically proven radiosensitizer. Regional hyperthermia for pelvic tumors, including cervical, rectal, bladder and prostate carcinoma, is applied using phased arrays of multiple Microwave (MW) or Radiofrequent (RF) antennas. A challenge in achieving high tumor temperatures is avoiding excessive normal tissue heating, or so-called hot spots. Hot spots are related to anatomical structures, specifically interfaces of tissues with different power absorption rates (SAR). Establishing optimal antenna settings preventing hot spots is complex due to tissue and perfusion heterogeneity and the large number of antennas. This task is performed using Hyperthermia Treatment Planning (HTP), but the accuracy of present tissue input data is limited and the computed system settings are thus not optimal, leading to treatment limiting hot spots and suboptimal tumor temperatures. 

4 Purpose 
We will improve the reliability of HTP by replacing the presently used generic literature values for dielectric tissue properties by patient specific data based on MR imaging as input for HTP. This will yield a more reliable prediction of hot spot location and amplitude, and thus yield system settings resulting in higher tumor temperatures and less toxicity.

profile_positions.title: Principal Investigator

profile_positions.description:
1988-1992: Project on the representation of blood flow in thermal models used in hyperthermia treatment planning, resulting in PhD thesis ‘verification of thermal models’ (University of Utrecht 1993). 
1992-1997: Development of a system for clinical application of interstitial hyperthermia with spatial power control for improved temperature uniformity in the tumor.
1997-1999: Clinical application of interstitial hyperthermia for brain and prostate implants.
